awd_titl_txt: Order Determination for Hidden Markov and Related Models
awd_abstract_narration:
Hidden Markov models (HMMs) are powerful tools for processing time series data and are widely used in scientific and engineering applications, including speech recognition, machine translation, computational biology, cryptanalysis, and finance. The fundamental components of an HMM include the noisy observations and the corresponding hidden states. In most applications, the number of hidden states (the order of the HMM) is not known beforehand but conveys important information about the underlying process. For example, in molecular biology, the total number of hidden states may be the number of distinct 3D conformations of a protein; in chemistry, the total number of hidden states may be the number of distinct chemical species in an organic reaction. This project plans to investigate order determination for HMMs, finite mixture models, and hierarchical HMMs; the latter two models are special cases and extensions of HMMs. The project aims to develop a consistent and competitive method for order selection. In addition to a thorough theoretical investigation, comprehensive numerical studies and applications in biology and chemistry will be conducted. The project will not only significantly advance the theoretical understanding of HMMs, but also provide powerful tools for researchers to analyze data. The data applications will help advance molecular biology and biochemistry. The project also aims to support and train undergraduate and graduate students, with special attention being given to recruiting students from under-represented groups into statistics and related fields. Education at the undergraduate and graduate levels will be integrated into the research activities. 

The project will establish the marginal likelihood method as a consistent and competitive order selection method for HMMs, finite mixture models, and hierarchical HMMs. Five research studies will be carried out, enumerated as follows. (1) Investigate the order of HMMs, where the goal is to identify and develop consistent methods for HMM order determination. (2) Investigate order selection issues in finite mixture models. Finite mixture models can be reformulated as special types of HMMs. The goal is to develop a method for consistently estimating the number of mixture components. (3) Investigate order determination of hierarchical HMMs, where multiple HMMs are linked through a hierarchical structure. The aim here is to identify and develop consistent methods for determining the order of hierarchical HMMs, taking special effort to address the challenging issue that multiple HMMs often have quite diverse characteristics, such as lengths. (4) Study computational challenges and investigate and implement efficient computational methods for the order determination of HMM and related models, including the implementation and release of an open source, publicly available R package. (5) Apply the new method to ion channel data and single-molecule data on co-translational protein targeting. The PI also plans to develop courses that introduce and guide students in HMMs, mixture models, and hierarchical HMMs. The success of the proposed research will develop a theoretical basis and associated methodology for consistent order determination of HMMs and related models. The research achievements and the education components will broadly impact the analysis of HMMs, hierarchical HMMs, and model selection and also help train a new generation of scholars and researchers in the field.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Hidden Markov models (HMMs) are powerful tools for describing noisy observations from a stochastic system. They are popular for processing time series data and are widely used in scientific and engineering applications, including speech recognition, machine translation, computational biology, cryptanalysis, economics, finance, and epidemiology. The basic components of an HMM include the observations and the corresponding Markovian hidden states. In most real-world problems, the number of hidden states, a.k.a. the order of the HMM, is not known beforehand but conveys important information of the underlying process, for example, the number of different conformations that a protein can take. Practitioners of HMMs often must specify the number of states of the HMM before applying them to analyzing real-world data. However, conventional methods (including AIC, BIC and minimum description length) are not able to give consistent estimate of the number of states, when the observations are continuous (as in the case of the popular Gaussian HMM, where the noise is Gaussian with unknown variance), often resulting in overfitted model. Our method and the corresponding theoretical results significantly advance our understanding of HMMs and their number-of-states estimation. We not only found the competitive order determination method and gave its explicit formulation, but also rigorously proved that our method is statistically consistent. In other words, practitioners can simply use our method with the assurance that the resulting estimation of the order of the HMM obtained from our method has the theoretical guarantee.


As HMMs are widely used in many scientific and engineering domains, our methods and the statistical theory have far-reaching impact. They can be applied by researchers from various scientific fields for analyzing real data, leading to exciting results.


Chen, Fuh, Kao and Kou (2019) proposed an empirical Bayes marginal likelihood method for the order determination of HMMs and finite mixture models, and rigorously proved the consistency of the proposed method. Our results provide major theoretical advances over existing methods, as these conventional methods are shown to be not consistent for the order determination of HMMs, whereas we rigorously established the consistency of our proposed method.


Ning, Yang and Kou (2019, Scientific Reports, 9, 5238) applied HMM to combine information from internet users' search data and historical influenza activity (recorded by CDC) for influenza forecasting at the regional level (on top of the national level). Our method has significantly outperformed all existing regional influenza forecasting methods

Du and Kou (2020), published in Statistical Science, one of the leading journals of statistics, systematically reviewed HMMs and related models in the field of single-molecule experiments.


Huang, Stein, Rubin and Kou (2020), published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, one of the leading journals in science, proposed a method, which addresses one of the major challenges in Bayesian analysis: how to specify prior distributions when the model understudy is complex. The proposed method, catalytic priors, is not only simple to formulate and interpret, but also easy to implement, in addition to having many desirable theoretical properties.


Yang, Yu, Palmer, Fox, Kou and Kohane (2020), published in Clinical Pharmacology & Therapeutics, studied the causal relationship between lung cancer immunotherapy and the development of autoimmune diseases. Using a matching method (based on finite mixture models), we found that immunotherapy treatment on lung cancer causes more autoimmune diseases compared to conventional chemotherapy treatment.


Yang, Ning and Kou (2021), published in Scientific Reports, applied HMM to combine information from internet users? search data and historical influenza activity for influenza forecasting at the state level. The model uses and combines data from multiple resolutions (national, regional and state), and significantly outperforms all the state-of-art state-level influenza forecasting methods.


Yi, Ning, Chang and Kou (2021), published in the Journal of American Statistical Association, the flagship journal of statistics, applied HMM to use information from historical unemployment numbers and internet users? search activity to estimate weekly unemployment claims in the US. The result significantly outperforms all existing forecasting methods.


Yang, Wong and Kou (2021), published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, introduced a method that use HMM-related method to do parameter estimation of differential equation models, which are widely used in science and engineering applications. The proposed method is not only statistically principled, but also fast. It can successfully handle missing data cases, as one would often encounter in real-world data, which has challenged the scientific community over decades.


The grant helped the PI to translate the current and ongoing research for classroom teaching; simplified versions of our methods have been successfully applied in the lectures for both undergraduate and graduate students. The grant also helped support and train Ph. D. students to prepare for research career. Graduate students received rigorous training on theory, model building, computation and model application. The projects they worked on contributed significantly to their Ph.D. research development and their career development.
